title: 107_hr5241
content: The Act titled "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2002" amends the Public Health Service Act by adding a new section on Lifespan Respite Care. This section includes findings and purposes related to respite care services. Congress finds that millions of individuals in the United States provide care for family members with various health conditions, including children with chronic illnesses and disabilities, those living with relatives due to parental incapacity, and elders with multiple disabling conditions. Approximately 4 million individuals in the United States have mental retardation or developmental disabilities and live with their families. Nearly 25% of the nation's elders have multiple chronic disabling conditions, requiring assistance with daily needs. Around 600,000 Americans die at home each year, often relying on extensive family caregiving. 42% of individuals needing daily living assistance in the US are under 65. There is a lack of resources to replace family caregivers with paid workers, which would cost approximately $200 billion annually. The family caregiver role is rewarding but can lead to emotional, physical, and financial hardships. The family caregiver role is personally rewarding but can result in substantial emotional, physical, and financial hardship. Approximately 75 percent of family caregivers are women. Family caregivers often struggle to find information about available respite care. Available respite care programs are insufficient and primarily cater to lower-income populations and the elderly. There is a limited number of respite care programs that have difficulty recruiting trained workers. The purpose of this title is to encourage the establishment of State and local lifespan respite care programs. The purpose of this title is to encourage States to establish State and local lifespan respite care programs, improve respite care information dissemination to family caregivers, provide respite care services, promote innovative approaches to respite care delivery and training, and support research on effective respite care services. The purpose of this section is to support training programs for family caregivers to make informed decisions about respite care services, conduct evaluative research on effective respite care services, and promote the dissemination of results and findings related to respite care delivery and caregiver training. "Definition section (SEC. 2802) outlines key terms related to respite care services and caregiver training." The term 'condition' in this title includes various health and developmental issues such as Alzheimer's disease, physical disabilities, chronic illness, and traumatic brain injury. An 'eligible recipient' refers to a State agency or any other public entity capable of providing services. The term 'eligible recipient' includes State agencies, public entities, nonprofit organizations, political subdivisions with a population of at least 3,000,000 individuals, and recognized State respite coordinating agencies with specific capabilities. The curr_chunk discusses the qualifications required for individuals working with State and community-based agencies, understanding respite care and family caregiver issues, and ensuring the involvement of family members. It defines 'family caregiver' as an unpaid individual providing in-home care for a child or adult with special needs. Additionally, it defines 'lifespan respite care' as a system of accessible respite services for family caregivers, and 'respite care' as planned or emergency care for individuals with special needs. The curr_chunk defines terms like respite care, Secretary, and special need in the context of providing coordinated respite services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. The curr_chunk focuses on Lifespan Respite Care Grants and Cooperative Agreements under SEC. 2803. The section aims to expand respite care services for family caregivers, improve dissemination and coordination, and enhance access and quality of services to reduce caregiver strain. The Secretary may award grants to eligible recipients for this purpose. Coordination of respite care services across different agencies is emphasized, ensuring support for caregivers of individuals of all ages with special needs. The National Family Caregiver Support Program, along with other agencies, must coordinate respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. Eligible recipients must submit an application to the Secretary, demonstrating their understanding of respite care and family caregiver issues, capacity for meaningful involvement of family members, caregivers, and care recipients, and collaboration with other State entities. The application for respite care services must include a description of the population of family caregivers, their respite care needs, existing services, and unmet needs. Collaboration with other agencies is also required. The respite care application must detail the population's respite care needs, existing services, unmet needs, coordination methods, and how grant funds will support information dissemination, services, recruitment, and training programs. The respite care application must include plans for collaboration, coordination with other services, participation of the population in planning, and maximizing the use of grant funds for training programs. The respite care application must include plans for collaboration with relevant agencies, maximizing the use of funds, improving coordination of services, identifying eligible family caregivers, and addressing unmet needs in the locality. The respite care application must include plans for coordination, distribution, and monitoring of respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. This includes identifying eligible caregivers, ensuring quality and safety of services, evaluating results, and maintaining a system for service delivery. The Secretary establishes a panel to review respite care applications, meeting as needed to evaluate and make recommendations for approval. Grants or cooperative agreements are awarded based on the panel's recommendations. The Secretary establishes a panel to review and evaluate respite care applications, making recommendations for approval. Grants or cooperative agreements are awarded based on the panel's recommendations, with priority given to those likely to implement or enhance lifespan respite care statewide. Grant funds must be used for developing lifespan respite care at the State and local levels. The Secretary may award grants for developing lifespan respite care at State and local levels, providing respite care services, and evaluating effectiveness. Recipients can subcontract with public or nonprofit agencies. Grants are awarded for a maximum of 5 years. The Secretary may award grants for respite care services for up to 5 years, allowing for renewal. Funds must supplement, not supplant, other available federal, state, and local funds. The Secretary will award a grant to establish a National Resource Center on Lifespan Respite Care. The Center will maintain a national database, provide training and assistance to respite care programs, and offer information and educational programs to the public. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose.
